Personally, I use my own small tool called testAssure to he=
lp me do fine grained unit testing.

The problem with arriving at the parti=
cular state is the information that is required to be set up... some of whi=
ch is hidden in private state variables.  Instead of creating public get an=
d set methods (ie. those that are only necessary during testing), the tool =
does the following....

1. It converts all private and protected variables =
and methods to public (for a particular directory) so that test methods can=
 exploit this information to setup data.

2.  It "enables" the special test=
s in your test code so that they can be run (ie. I convert a private method=
 to public and now my test code can use this information).

3. The system c=
an undo all changes above..

The main advantage to this tool is that you ca=
n continue doing regular testing (ie everything works fine without running =
the tool), and when you are using the testAssure you can access the interna=
l variables directly to do "real" unit testing.

The tool was developped as=
 a proof of concept project last December, and I will be adding a more func=
tional front end in March.

The concepts behind the tool are contained with=
in a (as of yet not published) pattern language concerning in-line testing =
(similar to XP test-first, but less stringent on the notion of testing befo=
re you write code) as well as few ppt presentations.
